item.title: Why I Add Creatine to My Coffee Every Morning (And You Should Too)
item.description:
Podcast: The Human Upgrade: Biohacking for Longevity & Performance

Date: 1994-07-03

Summary:

The episode dives into the surprising intersection of everyday routines and optimal health, focusing specifically on the host’s daily habit of adding creatine to his morning coffee. Drawing from both personal experience and scientific research, the host challenges common misconceptions about creatine supplementation. Listeners are invited to reconsider what they know about this widely misunderstood compound and to learn why it might deserve a spot in their own morning rituals. A central point of discussion is the persistent myth that creatine is harmful to kidney health. The host repeatedly highlights how this belief has been debunked by numerous studies, stating, “Creatine wrecks your kidneys” only to clarify that this notion is outdated and inaccurate. Instead, he emphasizes the safety and broad benefits of creatine when used responsibly, particularly for individuals seeking to enhance cognitive performance, muscle recovery, and general wellbeing. The episode also explores the synergy between creatine and coffee. The host explains that coffee, already a staple for many due to its energizing properties, can actually serve as an ideal vehicle for creatine supplementation. He notes, “Adding creatine to my coffee every morning is one of the simplest ways to stack benefits without extra effort.” This practical advice is complemented by references to scientific literature supporting the combination’s effectiveness. As the conversation draws to a close, the host encourages listeners to re-examine their supplement routines and to remain open to evidence-based changes that can elevate their health. He underscores the importance of questioning popular health myths and making decisions based on the latest research, rather than outdated fears or anecdotal reports. The actionable takeaway is clear: consider integrating creatine into your daily routine, especially if you are already a coffee drinker. Reflecting on the episode, it becomes evident that the host’s mission is to empower listeners with practical, research-backed guidance for everyday wellness. By demystifying creatine and advocating for small, impactful changes, the episode exemplifies how science and habit can intersect for better health. The discussion serves as a reminder to challenge conventional wisdom and to always seek out credible information when making choices about our bodies and minds. ]]>

item.title: From Architect To Ai Exec Scaling Leadership, Maintaining Credibility & Effective Communication To
item.description:
Podcast: The Engineering Leadership Podcast

Date: 2025-05-26

Summary:

In this episode of The Engineering Leadership Podcast, hosts Jerry Li and Patrick Gallagher engage in a compelling conversation with Prashant Ramarao, SVP of Engineering and Head of AI at Yahoo, about his journey from a deeply technical individual contributor (IC) to a high-level executive leading over 100 engineers. The discussion centers on the challenges of scaling leadership, maintaining technical credibility, and effectively communicating with non-technical executives, especially within the rapidly evolving AI landscape. Prashant’s story offers valuable lessons for engineers transitioning into leadership roles and those navigating AI-driven innovation in product development.

Prashant shares how he initially spent most of his career as an IC before gradually moving into management, starting with a small team of senior distinguished engineers. This early management experience was unique because these engineers were highly independent and technically proficient, requiring him to focus on coaching around soft skills and helping them navigate organizational dynamics. A pivotal moment came around 2018, when as a chief architect at Yahoo, he identified machine learning and deep learning as crucial areas for investment and skill-building. He spearheaded training efforts that equipped over 300 employees with machine learning expertise, positioning himself as a natural leader for Yahoo’s AI initiatives.

A key insight from Prashant is the importance of maintaining technical credibility while scaling leadership responsibilities. He emphasizes the need to experiment personally with emerging technologies to avoid being swayed by hype, stating, “Because this stuff is so new, I want a first-hand experience and exposure to this so that I know when somebody comes and tries to sell me something on a cool new project that we should be doing, I can kind of argue and kind of ask the right questions.” This hands-on approach not only strengthens his expertise but also builds trust with both technical teams and executive stakeholders. Furthermore, Prashant highlights the delicate balance of communicating complex AI topics in accessible ways for non-technical executives, ensuring alignment and informed decision-making.

The episode concludes with practical takeaways for engineering leaders facing similar transitions. Prashant’s journey illustrates that evolving from a technical specialist to a strategic leader requires continuous learning, empathy, and clear communication. Leaders must nurture their teams’ technical growth while cultivating soft skills such as persuasion and vision articulation. Additionally, staying grounded through personal experimentation with new technologies helps maintain authenticity and credibility. These strategies empower leaders to guide large, diverse teams effectively and drive impactful innovation.

Reflecting on the episode’s significance, Prashant’s experience offers a blueprint for engineers aspiring to leadership roles in the AI era. His story underscores the evolving demands on tech leaders—not just to be experts but also to be effective communicators and strategic thinkers. As AI continues to reshape industries, the ability to bridge technical depth with executive insight becomes increasingly vital. This conversation enriches the leadership discourse by blending personal narrative with actionable advice, inspiring listeners to embrace both the technical and human aspects of engineering leadership.
